headshotImage.longCaption: RG Sharma headshot

dismissalText.commentary: Angelo Mathews c Sharma b Bumrah 113 (128b 10x4 2x6 157m) SR: 88.28

dismissalComment.html: gone. Not quite in the blockhole, on off stump, and Mathews actually times that really well, making a bit of room and punch-driving, but it's in the air at catchable height, and straight to extra-cover. A few meters either side of him, and that could have been a boundary. End of a wonderful knock, walks off acknowledging a big ovation. Is this the last we'll see of Mathews with the bat in a World Cup match?

headshotImage.caption: RA Jadeja headshot
headshotImage.longCaption: RA Jadeja headshot

dismissalText.commentary: Lahiru Thirimanne c Jadeja b Kuldeep Yadav 53 (68b 4x4 0x6 102m) SR: 77.94

dismissalComment.html: down the track, and Thirimanne goes against the run of play. Kuldeep's slowness and dip does him in. Wants to make room and hit over extra-cover, but the ball dips shorter than he wants, and turns away. Ends up slicing it instead for a simple catch to Jadeja taking a couple of backward steps at backward point

headshotImage.caption: Jasprit Bumrah player page headshot cutout, 2021
headshotImage.longCaption: Jasprit Bumrah player page headshot cutout, 2021

headshotImage.caption: Dimuth Karunaratne, player page headshot cutout 2023
headshotImage.longCaption: Dimuth Karunaratne, player page headshot cutout 2023

dismissalComment.html: gone, is it? Dhoni's convinced, and Karunaratne begins walking. Width on this occasion, but it isn't short enough to cut, and he plays it with an angled bat rather than a horizontal bat, and only manages a top edge

headshotImage.caption: Kusal Perera player page headshot cutout 2021
headshotImage.longCaption: Kusal Perera player page headshot cutout 2021

dismissalComment.html: is that an edge? There was a sound, and both Sri Lankan openers have walked. Bumrah's been getting the ball to straighten against his angle all through this spell, and it happens again. Slants across the left-hander, straightens back just a touch, and Kusal, looking to punch to mid-on, gets an inside edge on it that Dhoni does well to catch, falling low to his right. On TV, Kumar Sangakkara notes that Kusal's bat was coming down from gully, and slicing across the line as a result

dismissalComment.html: Gone! Impatience gets the better of Mendis, and Jadeja finds turn in his first over. A little slower than usual, and he jumps out of his crease, but he gets nowhere near the pitch of the ball. Flails desperately at it, looking to hit over mid-off, maybe, and the ball spins past his outside edge. Dhoni does the rest

dismissalText.commentary: Avishka Fernando c Dhoni b Pandya 20 (21b 4x4 0x6 42m) SR: 95.23

dismissalComment.html: gone, and Hardik Pandya's slower-ball bouncer continues to take wickets. It's angling into the batsman, cramping him for room, and gets up to shoulder height. Looks to lean away and ramp it towards third man, but it keeps following him, and when the edge is taken, it's very close to the shoulder of the bat. The ball dies on its way through to Dhoni, who takes another very good catch, tumbling to his left and taking it inches off the ground

dismissalText.commentary: Thisara Perera c Pandya b Kumar 2 (3b 0x4 0x6 8m) SR: 66.66

dismissalComment.html: slower ball, fullish, slanting into a wide-ish line outside off. Looks to hit over long-off, but doesn't time it at all, and Pandya takes a stunner to send him back, running in off the long-off boundary, getting up towards the 30-yard circle, and dives forward to take it with two hands. Shades of Ajay Jadeja catching Allan Border in the 1992 World Cup

dismissalText.commentary: KL Rahul c MDKJ Perera b Malinga 111 (118b 11x4 1x6 180m) SR: 94.06

dismissalComment.html: edged, and Malinga gets the late breakthrough! A short ball, doesn't get up, but follows Rahul as he limboes inside the line, and scuffs the faintest of edges through to the keeper! A brilliant hundred is ended by a champion bowler in the final moments of his World Cup career!

dismissalText.commentary: Rohit Sharma c Mathews b Rajitha 103 (94b 14x4 2x6 133m) SR: 109.57

dismissalComment.html: wow. A moment of disbelieving silence in the crowd. Full, close to off stump, and it's the slower ball - did Rohit not pick it? Did he not watch it out of the bowler's hand, momentarily distracted after getting to his hundred? Who knows. He plays a checked drive and spoons it straight to mid-off

dismissalComment.html: slower ball, swinging into a riotous pull, a polite appeal, and Sri Lanka are reviewing! It's not a terrible shout, actually. Misses the bat, and thumped him right amidships ... is it hitting the stumps? It certainly is! Middle stump on the one hand, leg stump on the other! A late bonus for Sri Lanka

commentTextItems.html: loopy slower ball, outswinger almosts deceives the batsman, but instead is deflected to third man to seal a thumping, momentum-seizing win!

commentPostTextItems.html: 6.20pm So, that just about wraps it up from Headingley. India have done all they can to make a statement ahead of the knock-outs. It's all about Old Trafford now, and how Australia can respond to South Africa's hefty total. Win, and they face New Zealand on the same ground on Tuesday. Lose, and it's off to Edgbaston to face England on Thursday. And vice versa for India. Tune in now! But from myself, Andrew Miller, and Karthik and Chandan, goodbye!

Virat Kohli: "We wanted to play good cricket but didn't expect 7-1 (results). It's a real honour to play together for India. More or less everything is set for the semis, but we don't want to be one-dimensional. We have to turn up on the day and put in another performance."
"For us the opposition never matters, if we don't play well anyone can beat us, if we play well we can beat anyone."
Hardik Pandya's bowling: "He's really motivated for this tournament, hes thinking like a batsman, which helps, it's amazing to have a cricketer like that who can bring so much to the table."

Dimuth Karunaratne: "We ended up with close to 280 which was a good score. We kept losing wickets, and didn't capitalise on a good start, we had to rebuild which is why we got 260. But Rohit and Rahul batted really well."
"We have to think about what we got wrong, talk to the selectors and high-performance centre to identify some new talents. Four years is a long time [until the next World Cup]."

On Malinga: "Sri Lankan cricket will miss him, in Test cricket and one-day cricket, he was the man, he's done a really good job. Everyone has to end their chapter, and we have to find a new guy, as we lacked bowlers to get wickets in the middle parts."

6.11pm Naveen Kumar S.: "Interesting, Joe root is watching neither of these matches. He says he would rather sit in a wimbledon box on this fine saturday evening, watching a Federer #Wimbledon #Round3 #FederervsPouille" Can't say I blame him! Lovely evening for it, and England have got a few days off now to not think about cricket. They'll be back on it like a bonnet before long...

6.10pm Speaking of total control, few players have been as dominant as Pankaj Advani in billiards and snooker. With a staggering 21 world titles to his name, the Indian won the only piece of silverware missing in his trophy cabinet - the Asian snooker championship - last month. How does a player of this calibre remain hungry? Have a read to know more.

The man of the match is Rohit Sharma "I wasn't thinking about milestones, my job is to keep my head straight and get the team towards the finishing line. When you are in, shot selection becomes very important, I try to calculate how I want to go forward, and it has paid dividends, You have to be disciplined in batting, and I've learned from my mistakes in the past."
"Every day is a new day, I start fresh, I try to think I've not played any ODIs, not got any hundreds in the tournament. The challenge as a sportsman is to keep your head straight."

On Malinga, "Lasith Malinga is a champion, a  match-winner, the team relies on him to deliver, and he has done that. I've seen him at close quarters [for Mumbai Indians], and world cricket will miss him."
On their potential semi-final opponents, "we're not thinking of that..." Of course not ...
6.08pm Meanwhile at Old Trafford, Australia have lost an early wicket... it's looking increasingly like India will be facing New Zealand....drama!
6.05pm WATCH on Hotstar (India only): Highlights of Rohit Sharma's fifth century of the World Cup

Deepanshu Khand: "Salute and farewell to Ian Gould as well. What a prolific umpiring career it has been for this man! One of the great umpires of our times, specially when umpiring has been under scanner. Great man, great umpire and great character!"

6pm Handshakes all round on the dot of 6pm... India are top of the group-stage table at the last gasp ... and who knows, they might yet be staying there, depending on how Australia's chase at Old Trafford pans out... it's a statement chase from India, who will be a side to be feared in the semi-finals. But who will they face ... England, or New Zealand?
Handshakes for Malinga as he bows out of World Cup cricket, and umpire Gunner Gould as well.

commentTextItems.html: patted down to third man. Scores are level
back of a length, blocked back to the bowler
attempted the trademark yorker to finish, comes out as a full-toss, and clobbered through midwicket! It wasn't to be for Malinga ... India on the brink now

commentPostTextItems.html: The end of a storied World Cup career. it's not been his day today, but Malinga's raging against the dying of the light inspired Sri Lanka to greater heights than anyone expected in this World Cup. Farewell, legend!

commentPreTextItems.html: Hardik Pandya has been sent up the order to finish this in a hurry... here's Malinga for his final World Cup over

commentTextItems.html: sliding into the legs, worked behind square

dismissalText.commentary: Rishabh Pant lbw b Udana 4 (4b 1x4 0x6 6m) SR: 100

commentTextItems.html: slower ball, swinging into a riotous pull, a polite appeal, and Sri Lanka are reviewing! It's not a terrible shout, actually. Misses the bat, and thumped him right amidships ... is it hitting the stumps? It certainly is! Middle stump on the one hand, leg stump on the other! A late bonus for Sri Lanka

headshotImage.longCaption: V Kohli headshot

headshotImage.caption: Isuru Udana  player page headshot cutout, 2021
headshotImage.longCaption: Isuru Udana  player page headshot cutout, 2021

headshotImage.caption: SL Malinga headshot
headshotImage.longCaption: SL Malinga headshot

commentTextItems.html: thumped to mid-off

commentPostTextItems.html: Bharath Seervi at your seervice: Malinga's second-most expensive returns in a WC match

commentTextItems.html: bottom-handed belligerence! Full length, and dismissively slapped back past the stumps!
swinging into the toes, pushed with the angle to mid-on
deflected down to third man
gorgeous! Kohli's cover-drives have all been a rehearsal for that one, utterly nailed through the covers with the most serene of followthroughs

dismissalText.commentary: KL Rahul c MDKJ Perera b Malinga 111 (118b 11x4 1x6 180m) SR: 94.06

commentTextItems.html: edged, and Malinga gets the late breakthrough! A short ball, doesn't get up, but follows Rahul as he limboes inside the line, and scuffs the faintest of edges through to the keeper! A brilliant hundred is ended by a champion bowler in the final moments of his World Cup career!

commentPostTextItems.html: And with that wicket, Malinga went past Wasim Akram to No. 3 in highest WC wicket-takers list. Shabash!

commentTextItems.html: slow bouncer, picked off the hips with a measured paddle to square leg
more full-faced elegance from Kohli, just a gentle push to cover
helicoptered off the toes, sizing up the inswinging yorker and flicking it up and over the leg side. That's the shot of a man seeing it very well indeed

dismissalText.commentary: Kusal Perera c Dhoni b Bumrah 18 (14b 3x4 0x6 36m) SR: 128.57

dismissalComment.html: is that an edge? There was a sound, and both Sri Lankan openers have walked. Bumrah's been getting the ball to straighten against his angle all through this spell, and it happens again. Slants across the left-hander, straightens back just a touch, and Kusal, looking to punch to mid-on, gets an inside edge on it that Dhoni does well to catch, falling low to his right. On TV, Kumar Sangakkara notes that Kusal's bat was coming down from gully, and slicing across the line as a result

dismissalText.commentary: Avishka Fernando c Dhoni b Pandya 20 (21b 4x4 0x6 42m) SR: 95.23

dismissalComment.html: gone, and Hardik Pandya's slower-ball bouncer continues to take wickets. It's angling into the batsman, cramping him for room, and gets up to shoulder height. Looks to lean away and ramp it towards third man, but it keeps following him, and when the edge is taken, it's very close to the shoulder of the bat. The ball dies on its way through to Dhoni, who takes another very good catch, tumbling to his left and taking it inches off the ground

dismissalText.commentary: Kusal Mendis st Dhoni b Jadeja 3 (13b 0x4 0x6 15m) SR: 23.07

dismissalComment.html: Gone! Impatience gets the better of Mendis, and Jadeja finds turn in his first over. A little slower than usual, and he jumps out of his crease, but he gets nowhere near the pitch of the ball. Flails desperately at it, looking to hit over mid-off, maybe, and the ball spins past his outside edge. Dhoni does the rest

dismissalText.commentary: Angelo Mathews c Sharma b Bumrah 113 (128b 10x4 2x6 157m) SR: 88.28

dismissalComment.html: gone. Not quite in the blockhole, on off stump, and Mathews actually times that really well, making a bit of room and punch-driving, but it's in the air at catchable height, and straight to extra-cover. A few meters either side of him, and that could have been a boundary. End of a wonderful knock, walks off acknowledging a big ovation. Is this the last we'll see of Mathews with the bat in a World Cup match?

dismissalText.commentary: Lahiru Thirimanne c Jadeja b Kuldeep Yadav 53 (68b 4x4 0x6 102m) SR: 77.94

dismissalComment.html: down the track, and Thirimanne goes against the run of play. Kuldeep's slowness and dip does him in. Wants to make room and hit over extra-cover, but the ball dips shorter than he wants, and turns away. Ends up slicing it instead for a simple catch to Jadeja taking a couple of backward steps at backward point

dismissalText.commentary: Thisara Perera c Pandya b Kumar 2 (3b 0x4 0x6 8m) SR: 66.66

dismissalComment.html: slower ball, fullish, slanting into a wide-ish line outside off. Looks to hit over long-off, but doesn't time it at all, and Pandya takes a stunner to send him back, running in off the long-off boundary, getting up towards the 30-yard circle, and dives forward to take it with two hands. Shades of Ajay Jadeja catching Allan Border in the 1992 World Cup

dismissalText.commentary: Rohit Sharma c Mathews b Rajitha 103 (94b 14x4 2x6 133m) SR: 109.57

dismissalComment.html: wow. A moment of disbelieving silence in the crowd. Full, close to off stump, and it's the slower ball - did Rohit not pick it? Did he not watch it out of the bowler's hand, momentarily distracted after getting to his hundred? Who knows. He plays a checked drive and spoons it straight to mid-off

dismissalComment.html: edged, and Malinga gets the late breakthrough! A short ball, doesn't get up, but follows Rahul as he limboes inside the line, and scuffs the faintest of edges through to the keeper! A brilliant hundred is ended by a champion bowler in the final moments of his World Cup career!

dismissalComment.html: wow. A moment of disbelieving silence in the crowd. Full, close to off stump, and it's the slower ball - did Rohit not pick it? seriesStandings.notes:
League Stage
In the event of teams finishing on equal points
* The team with the most wins in the League Stage will be placed in the higher position.
* If there are teams with equal points and equal wins in the League Stage then in such case the teams will be ordered according to their net run rate in the League Stage matches.
* If there are teams that are still equal, they will be ordered according to the result(s) of the head to head match(es) played between them (points, then if still equal, net run rate in those matches).
* If the above does not resolve the League Stage ordering and there are teams that are still equal, the teams will be ordered as per their League Stage seedings.
* If all matches in the League Stage produce no results the teams will be ordered as per their League Stage seedings and the top 4 seeded teams will progress to Semi-Finals.
Semi Final
If a Semi-Final is tied, the teams shall compete in a Super Over to determine which team progresses to the Final.
If following a tie, weather conditions prevent the Super Over from being completed, or if the match is abandoned or a no result at the end of the reserve day, then the team which proceeds to the Final will be the team that finished in the higher position in the League Stage.
Final
In the event of a tied final, the teams shall compete in a Super Over to determine which team is the winner.
If following a tie, weather conditions prevent the Super Over from being completed, or if the match is abandoned or a no result at the end of the reserve day, the teams shall be declared joint winners.
